name: 1575_A. Another Sorting Problem
description:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
repair_prompt:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Each book has a unique title consisting of characters. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m, and each book has a unique title consisting of characters. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4

completion:
def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple of characters with odd-indexed sorted ascending and even-indexed sorted descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:2+n]
    
    # Sort titles using the custom sort key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_sort_key(titles[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the input
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    titles = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Sort the titles using the custom sort key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_sort_key(titles[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Extract the indices from the sorted list
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the input
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    book_titles = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(title):
        # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)))  # Even index: descending, Odd index: ascending
            for i, c in enumerate(title)
        )
    
    # Sort the book titles using the custom key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: asc_desc_ending_key(book_titles[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(title)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:n+2]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the input
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a key based on the asc-desc-ending order
        key = []
        for i, char in enumerate(title):
            if i % 2 == 0:
                # Odd-indexed (1-based) -> ascending
                key.append((char, 1))
            else:
                # Even-indexed (1-based) -> descending
                key.append((char, -1))
        return key
    
    # Sort the books using the custom comparator
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Output the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import sys

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((ord(c) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    
    titles = [(data[i + 2], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort titles using the custom sort key
    sorted_titles = sorted(titles, key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[0]))
    
    # Extract indices from sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_titles]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'lexicographically ascending' and 'lexicographically descending'
    Explanation: Lexicographical order is a generalization of the alphabetical order of the dictionaries to sequences of ordered symbols or, more generally, of elements of a totally ordered set. In this requirement, odd-indexed characters are sorted in ascending order (like a dictionary), and even-indexed characters are sorted in descending order (reverse dictionary order).

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No phrase showing quantity relationship

# [degree adverb] 
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    The steps in the plan related to defining and applying the custom sorting function should be implemented simultaneously. Specifically, the steps:
    - "For each pair of book titles, compare them character by character."
    - "If the characters differ at an odd index, sort them in ascending order."
    - "If the characters differ at an even index, sort them in descending order."
    These steps should be encapsulated within a single custom sorting function that can be applied to the list of book titles.

# [edge case] 
    1. Input: 1 1 \n A
       Output: 1
       Explanation: With only one book, the order remains the same.
    2. Input: 2 2 \n AA \n AB
       Output: 1 2
       Explanation: Both books have the same first character, and the second character is at an even index, so 'AA' comes before 'AB'.
    3. Input: 3 3 \n ABC \n ACB \n BAC
       Output: 1 3 2
       Explanation: The first character is the same for the first two books, so we look at the second character (even index), where 'C' comes before 'B'. For the third book, 'B' at the first position (odd index) comes after 'A'.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The custom sorting function inherently handles these cases by comparing characters at odd and even indices as specified.

# [core concept]
    'lexicographically ascending' and 'lexicographically descending'
    Explanation: Lexicographical order is the order in which words or strings are arranged in a dictionary. Ascending means from A to Z, and descending means from Z to A.

    'asc-desc-endingly'
    Explanation: This is a custom sorting order where odd-indexed characters are sorted in ascending order and even-indexed characters are sorted in descending order.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No explicit phrases showing quantity relationships are present in the requirement.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverbs are present in the requirement.

# [code logic]
    The steps related to sorting should be implemented simultaneously:
    - Implement a custom comparator function that compares two book titles based on the asc-desc-ending order.
    - Use the custom comparator to sort the list of book titles.
    These steps can be combined into a single sorting operation using a custom key or comparator function.

# [edge case]
    1. Input: 1 1
       A
       Output: 1
       Explanation: With only one book, the order remains the same.

    2. Input: 2 2
       AA
       AB
       Output: 1 2
       Explanation: Both books have the same first character, and the second character is compared in descending order, so 'AA' comes before 'AB'.

    3. Input: 3 3
       ABC
       ACB

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(title)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:n+2]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the input
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a key based on the asc-desc-ending order
        key = []
        for i, char in enumerate(title):
            if i % 2 == 0:
                # Odd-indexed (1-based) -> ascending
                key.append((char, 1))
            else:
                # Even-indexed (1-based) -> descending
                key.append((char, -1))
        return key
    
    # Sort the books using the custom comparator
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Output the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'lexicographically ascending' and 'lexicographically descending'
    Explanation: Lexicographical order is the order in which words or strings are arranged based on the alphabetical order of their component letters. Ascending means from A to Z, while descending means from Z to A.

    'asc-desc-endingly'

    - Use the custom comparator to sort the list of book titles.
    These steps are interdependent and should be executed together to achieve the desired sorting order.

# [edge case]
    1. Input: 1 1 \n A
       Output: 1
       Explanation: With only one book, the order remains unchanged.

    2. Input: 2 2 \n AA \n AB
       Output: 1 2
       Explanation: Both books have the same first character, and the second character is compared in descending order, so 'AA' comes before 'AB'.

    3. Input: 3 3 \n ABC \n ACB \n BAC
       Output: 1 3 2
       Explanation: The first character is the same for the first two books, so the second character is compared in descending order. For the third book, the first character is different and is compared in ascending order.

Round_0.code:
import sys

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((ord(c) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    
    titles = [(data[i + 2], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort titles using the custom sort key
    sorted_titles = sorted(titles, key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[0]))
    
    # Extract indices from sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_titles]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple of characters with odd-indexed sorted ascending and even-indexed sorted descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:2+n]
    
    # Sort titles using the custom sort key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_sort_key(titles[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

prompt:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Each book has a unique title consisting of characters. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
